canonical_explanation.text: Light is a form of energy that enables us to see objects. Light travels in straight lines, which is called rectilinear propagation. When light falls on a smooth, shiny surface like a mirror, it bounces back. This bouncing back of light is called reflection. The laws of reflection state that (1) the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection, and (2) the incident ray, reflected ray, and normal all lie in the same plane. A plane mirror forms an image that is virtual, erect, same size as the object, and laterally inverted. The image is as far behind the mirror as the object is in front. Concave mirrors (curved inward) converge light and are used in torches, headlights, and by dentists. Convex mirrors (curved outward) diverge light and are used as rear-view mirrors. White light is composed of seven colours (VIBGYOR), which can be separated by a prism. This splitting of white light is called dispersion. A rainbow is a natural example of dispersion.
rules: Light travels in straight lines (rectilinear propagation).
Reflection: bouncing back of light from a surface.
Laws of reflection: angle of incidence = angle of reflection; incident ray, reflected ray, and normal lie in the same plane.
Plane mirror image: virtual, erect, same size, laterally inverted, same distance behind mirror.
Concave mirror: reflecting surface curves inward, converges light.
Convex mirror: reflecting surface curves outward, diverges light.
Concave mirrors used in torches, headlights, shaving mirrors, dentist mirrors.
Convex mirrors used as rear-view mirrors in vehicles.
Dispersion: splitting of white light into seven colours by a prism.
VIBGYOR: Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, Red.
A rainbow is formed by dispersion of sunlight by water droplets.

questions.question_text: The bouncing back of light from a smooth surface is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The bouncing back of light when it hits a smooth surface like a mirror is called reflection. This is different from refraction (bending of light) and dispersion (splitting of light).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Refraction is the bending of light when it passes from one medium to another. Dispersion is the splitting of white light into colours. Absorption is when a surface takes in light energy. The bouncing back of light is specifically called reflection.

questions.question_text: According to the laws of reflection, the angle of incidence is:

options.text: Greater than the angle of reflection
Less than the angle of reflection
Equal to the angle of reflection
Unrelated to the angle of reflection

questions.explanation_correct: The first law of reflection states that the angle of incidence is always equal to the angle of reflection. This holds true for all types of reflecting surfaces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The law of reflection clearly states that the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection. It is neither greater, nor less, nor unrelated.

questions.question_text: The imaginary line drawn perpendicular to the reflecting surface at the point of incidence is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The normal is an imaginary line drawn perpendicular (at 90 degrees) to the reflecting surface at the point where the light ray hits. Angles of incidence and reflection are measured with respect to this normal.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'normal'. It is the reference line perpendicular to the surface used to measure the angles of incidence and reflection.

questions.question_text: Light travels in straight lines.
questions.explanation_correct: Light does travel in straight lines. This property is called rectilinear propagation of light and is the reason shadows are formed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Light travels in straight lines, which can be demonstrated by the formation of shadows and the passage of light through a small hole.

questions.question_text: The angle of incidence is measured between the:

options.text: Incident ray and the mirror surface
Reflected ray and the mirror surface

questions.explanation_correct: The angle of incidence is the angle between the incident ray (incoming light ray) and the normal (the line perpendicular to the surface at the point of incidence).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The angle of incidence is NOT measured from the mirror surface. It is measured between the incident ray and the normal (the perpendicular line to the surface at the point of incidence).

questions.question_text: The image formed by a plane mirror is:

options.text: Virtual, erect, and of the same size as the object

questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror always forms a virtual (cannot be caught on a screen), erect (upright), and same-sized image. The image is also laterally inverted (left and right are swapped).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plane mirrors always form virtual, erect, same-size images. They do not form real images, inverted images, magnified images, or diminished images.

questions.question_text: The image formed by a plane mirror is ___ inverted, meaning left appears as right.
questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror produces a laterally inverted image, meaning the left side of the object appears as the right side in the image and vice versa. This is why text appears reversed in a mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'laterally'. Lateral inversion means the swapping of left and right in the mirror image.

questions.question_text: If an object is placed 5 cm in front of a plane mirror, the image is formed 5 cm behind the mirror.
questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror forms an image at the same distance behind the mirror as the object is in front of it. If the object is 5 cm in front, the image is 5 cm behind the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The distance of the image from a plane mirror is always equal to the distance of the object from the mirror.

questions.question_text: A concave mirror has its reflecting surface curved:
questions.explanation_correct: A concave mirror has its reflecting surface curved inward, like the inside of a spoon. It converges (brings together) light rays that fall on it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A concave mirror curves inward, not outward. A convex mirror curves outward. A flat reflecting surface is a plane mirror.

questions.question_text: Which type of mirror is used as a rear-view mirror in vehicles?
questions.explanation_correct: Convex mirrors are used as rear-view mirrors because they always form erect (upright) and diminished (smaller) images, giving a wider field of view so the driver can see more of the road behind.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plane mirrors give a limited field of view and concave mirrors can form inverted images. Convex mirrors are preferred as rear-view mirrors because they provide a wider field of view.

questions.question_text: A convex mirror always forms a ___, erect, and diminished image.
questions.explanation_correct: A convex mirror always forms a virtual (cannot be obtained on a screen), erect (upright), and diminished (smaller than the object) image regardless of the position of the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'virtual'. Convex mirrors always produce virtual, erect, and diminished images.

questions.question_text: The splitting of white light into seven colours by a prism is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Dispersion is the splitting of white light into its component colours (VIBGYOR) when it passes through a prism. Different colours bend by different amounts, causing them to separate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Reflection is bouncing back of light, refraction is bending of light, and absorption is taking in of light. The splitting of white light into colours is specifically called dispersion.

questions.question_text: The correct order of colours in the spectrum (from top to bottom in a prism experiment) is:

options.text: Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, Indigo, Violet
Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, Red
Red, Yellow, Green, Blue, Violet, Indigo, Orange
Violet, Blue, Green, Red, Yellow, Orange, Indigo

questions.explanation_correct: In the spectrum formed by a prism, violet bends the most and appears at the bottom, while red bends the least and appears at the top. The sequence VIBGYOR (Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, Red) goes from bottom to top.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order from most bent (bottom) to least bent (top) is VIBGYOR: Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, Red.

questions.question_text: Sunlight (white light) is made up of seven colours.
questions.explanation_correct: White light (sunlight) is composed of seven colours: Violet, Indigo, Blue, Green, Yellow, Orange, and Red (VIBGYOR). This was demonstrated by Newton's prism experiment.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Newton showed that white light is a mixture of seven colours, which can be separated by passing white light through a prism.

questions.question_text: A ___ is a natural phenomenon in which sunlight is dispersed by water droplets in the atmosphere.
questions.explanation_correct: A rainbow is formed when sunlight is dispersed by tiny water droplets in the atmosphere. Each droplet acts like a tiny prism, splitting white light into its seven component colours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'rainbow'. A rainbow is the natural example of dispersion of sunlight by water droplets.

questions.question_text: Why does the word AMBULANCE appear written in reverse on the front of an ambulance?

options.text: So that it reads correctly in the rear-view mirror of vehicles ahead
Because the painter wrote it backwards by accident

questions.explanation_correct: The word AMBULANCE is written in reverse (mirror writing) on the front of an ambulance so that when a driver ahead looks in their rear-view mirror, the lateral inversion makes it read correctly as AMBULANCE.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is intentionally written in reverse so that the mirror image reads correctly. A plane mirror laterally inverts images, so a reversed word appears correct in the mirror.

questions.question_text: A concave mirror is also called a converging mirror because it brings parallel rays of light to a point.
questions.explanation_correct: A concave mirror converges (brings together) parallel rays of light to its focus (focal point). That is why it is also called a converging mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. A concave mirror reflects parallel rays of light so that they converge at the focus, earning it the name converging mirror.

questions.question_text: The incident ray, reflected ray, and normal all lie in the:
questions.explanation_correct: The second law of reflection states that the incident ray, the reflected ray, and the normal at the point of incidence all lie in the same plane.
questions.explanation_incorrect: According to the second law of reflection, the incident ray, reflected ray, and normal must all lie in the same plane. They cannot be in different or perpendicular planes.

questions.question_text: An image that cannot be obtained on a screen is called a ___ image.
questions.explanation_correct: A virtual image is one that cannot be caught or projected on a screen. It can only be seen by looking into the mirror or lens. Plane mirrors and convex mirrors always form virtual images.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'virtual'. Virtual images are formed when light rays appear to come from a point behind the mirror but do not actually meet there.

questions.question_text: Which mirror is used by dentists to see the enlarged image of teeth?
questions.explanation_correct: Dentists use concave mirrors because when the teeth (object) are placed close to the mirror (within the focal length), a concave mirror forms a virtual, erect, and magnified (enlarged) image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plane mirrors do not magnify. Convex mirrors always form diminished images. Concave mirrors form magnified images when the object is close, which is why dentists use them.

questions.question_text: If the angle of incidence is 35 degrees, what is the angle of reflection?
questions.explanation_correct: According to the law of reflection, the angle of incidence is always equal to the angle of reflection. If the angle of incidence is 35 degrees, the angle of reflection is also 35 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The law of reflection states angle of incidence = angle of reflection. So if the angle of incidence is 35 degrees, the angle of reflection must be 35 degrees.

questions.question_text: A light ray hits a plane mirror at an angle of 30 degrees to the mirror surface. What is the angle of incidence?
questions.explanation_correct: The angle of incidence is measured from the normal, not from the mirror surface. If the ray makes 30 degrees with the surface, it makes 90 - 30 = 60 degrees with the normal. So the angle of incidence is 60 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Remember that angles are measured from the normal, not the surface. If the ray is at 30 degrees to the surface, it is at 90 - 30 = 60 degrees to the normal.

questions.question_text: Riya stands 2 metres in front of a plane mirror. What is the distance between Riya and her image?
questions.explanation_correct: The image in a plane mirror is formed at the same distance behind the mirror as the object is in front. Riya is 2 m in front, so her image is 2 m behind. The distance between Riya and her image is 2 + 2 = 4 metres.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The image is 2 m behind the mirror and Riya is 2 m in front. Total distance between them = 2 + 2 = 4 metres.

questions.question_text: If you raise your right hand in front of a plane mirror, the image appears to raise its left hand.
questions.explanation_correct: Due to lateral inversion in a plane mirror, left and right are swapped. When you raise your right hand, the image appears to raise the left hand. This is why mirror images appear laterally inverted.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Lateral inversion causes the right side to appear as left and vice versa in a plane mirror.

questions.question_text: Why are convex mirrors preferred as rear-view mirrors over plane mirrors?

options.text: They provide a wider field of view

questions.explanation_correct: Convex mirrors form diminished images, which means they can show a wider area (larger field of view) than a plane mirror of the same size. This helps drivers see more of the road behind them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Convex mirrors are preferred because they provide a wider field of view, allowing drivers to see more of the road. The images are actually smaller (not larger), but the wider coverage is more useful.

questions.question_text: If a light ray falls perpendicular (at 90 degrees) to a plane mirror, it will:

options.text: Reflect at 90 degrees to the normal
Reflect back along the same path

questions.explanation_correct: When a light ray falls perpendicular to a mirror, the angle of incidence is 0 degrees (the ray is along the normal). By the law of reflection, the angle of reflection is also 0 degrees, so the ray reflects back along the same path.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A perpendicular ray has an angle of incidence of 0 degrees, so the angle of reflection is also 0 degrees. The ray retraces its path back.

questions.question_text: Which colour of light bends the most when passing through a prism?
questions.explanation_correct: Violet light bends the most when passing through a prism. This is because violet light has the shortest wavelength among the visible colours, causing it to slow down the most and bend the most.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Red light bends the least (longest wavelength) and violet bends the most (shortest wavelength). The order from most bending to least is VIBGYOR.

questions.question_text: In the visible spectrum, ___ light bends the least through a prism because it has the longest wavelength.
questions.explanation_correct: Red light has the longest wavelength among the visible colours and therefore bends the least when passing through a prism. It appears at the top of the spectrum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'red'. Red light has the longest wavelength and bends the least, appearing at the top of the spectrum formed by a prism.

questions.question_text: A torch uses a concave mirror behind the bulb. What is the purpose of this mirror?

options.text: To make the bulb look bigger
To reflect light in all directions
To reflect light into a strong, parallel beam
To split the light into colours

questions.explanation_correct: A concave mirror in a torch reflects the light from the bulb (placed at the focus) into a strong, parallel beam. This is why torch light travels a long distance without spreading much.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The concave mirror in a torch focuses the light into a parallel beam (when the bulb is at the focus). It does not spread light, make the bulb look bigger, or split light.

questions.question_text: Aman is standing 3 m from a plane mirror. He walks 1 m towards the mirror. By how much does the distance between him and his image change?
questions.explanation_correct: Initially, Aman is 3 m from mirror, image is 3 m behind = 6 m between him and image. After walking 1 m closer, he is 2 m from mirror, image is 2 m behind = 4 m between him and image. Change = 6 - 4 = 2 m.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When Aman walks 1 m towards the mirror, both he and his image get closer by 1 m each. So the total distance decreases by 1 + 1 = 2 m.

questions.question_text: If the angle of incidence is 0 degrees, the angle between the incident ray and reflected ray is also 0 degrees.
questions.explanation_correct: When the angle of incidence is 0 degrees (ray falls along the normal), the angle of reflection is also 0 degrees. The angle between the incident and reflected rays is therefore 0 degrees because the ray retraces its path.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. With both angles at 0 degrees, the incident and reflected rays lie along the same path (the normal), so the angle between them is 0 degrees.

questions.question_text: When is a rainbow commonly seen?

options.text: On a hot sunny day with no clouds
When the sun shines after or during rain, with the observer facing away from the sun

questions.explanation_correct: A rainbow is seen when sunlight is dispersed by water droplets in the atmosphere. The conditions are: the sun should be shining, there should be water droplets (after or during rain), and the observer should face away from the sun.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rainbow requires both sunlight and water droplets. It is seen when looking away from the sun with rain droplets in the sky ahead, typically just after or during rain.

questions.question_text: A ___ mirror is also called a diverging mirror because it spreads out the light rays falling on it.
questions.explanation_correct: A convex mirror is called a diverging mirror because it spreads out (diverges) parallel rays of light that fall on it. The reflected rays appear to come from a point behind the mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'convex'. A convex mirror diverges (spreads out) light rays, which is why it is called a diverging mirror.

questions.question_text: The angle between the incident ray and the reflected ray is 80 degrees. What is the angle of incidence?
questions.explanation_correct: The angle between the incident ray and reflected ray is the sum of the angle of incidence and the angle of reflection. Since both angles are equal, each is 80/2 = 40 degrees.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The angle between incident and reflected rays = angle of incidence + angle of reflection = 2 x angle of incidence. So angle of incidence = 80/2 = 40 degrees.

questions.question_text: Which of the following letters will look the same in a plane mirror?
questions.explanation_correct: The letter A is symmetrical about a vertical axis, so its mirror image (lateral inversion) looks the same as the original. Letters like B, R, and G are not symmetrical about the vertical axis and appear different in a mirror.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Letters that are symmetrical about a vertical line look the same in a mirror. A is symmetric, while B, R, and G are not (they would appear laterally inverted and look different).

questions.question_text: If two prisms are placed together in an inverted position, the colours separated by the first prism can be recombined into white light by the second prism.
questions.explanation_correct: If a second prism is placed in an inverted position, it recombines the dispersed colours back into white light. Newton demonstrated this, proving that a prism does not add colour to light but merely separates the colours already present in white light.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Newton used a second inverted prism to recombine the spectrum back into white light, proving that white light contains all seven colours.

questions.question_text: When you look at the inner (concave) side of a shiny steel spoon from close up, you see a magnified, erect image. If you move the spoon farther away, the image becomes:
questions.explanation_correct: When the object (your face) is within the focal length of a concave mirror (spoon), you see a magnified, erect image. As you move the object beyond the focal length, the image becomes inverted and eventually smaller.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A concave mirror produces a magnified erect image only when the object is very close. As the object moves away, the image becomes inverted and eventually diminished.

questions.question_text: A plane mirror always forms images that are the ___ size as the object.
questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror always produces an image that is exactly the same size as the object. It neither magnifies nor diminishes the image.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'same'. Plane mirrors produce images that are identical in size to the object.

questions.question_text: A student says: 'The angle of incidence is 40 degrees, so the angle between the reflected ray and the mirror surface is 50 degrees.' Is this correct?

options.text: Yes, because the angle of reflection is 50 degrees
Yes, because 90 - 40 = 50 degrees is the angle the reflected ray makes with the surface
No, the angle between reflected ray and surface is 40 degrees
No, the angle between reflected ray and surface is 80 degrees

questions.explanation_correct: The angle of incidence is 40 degrees (from the normal). The angle of reflection is also 40 degrees (from the normal). The angle between the reflected ray and the mirror surface = 90 - 40 = 50 degrees. The student is correct.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The angle of reflection from the normal is 40 degrees. Since the normal is at 90 degrees to the surface, the reflected ray makes 90 - 40 = 50 degrees with the surface. The student's answer is correct.

questions.question_text: In a room with two plane mirrors placed at right angles to each other, how many images of an object placed between them will be formed?
questions.explanation_correct: When two plane mirrors are placed at 90 degrees to each other, the number of images formed = (360/90) - 1 = 4 - 1 = 3 images. Each mirror forms one image, and there is one additional image formed by double reflection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The formula for images formed by two plane mirrors at angle theta is (360/theta) - 1. For 90 degrees: (360/90) - 1 = 3 images.

questions.question_text: A concave mirror is used in solar cookers. What is the reason?

options.text: It converges sunlight to a point, producing intense heat
It reflects sunlight away from the food

questions.explanation_correct: A concave mirror converges (focuses) parallel sunlight rays to its focal point. This concentration of light energy at a single point produces intense heat, which is enough to cook food.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The concave mirror in a solar cooker converges sunlight to a point (the focus), concentrating heat energy. It does not disperse light, reflect it away, or magnify food.

questions.question_text: Newton passed sunlight through a prism and obtained a spectrum. He then allowed only the red colour from the spectrum to pass through a second prism. What did he observe?

options.text: The red light split further into more colours
The red light remained red and did not split further
The red light turned into white light

questions.explanation_correct: When a single colour (like red) from the spectrum is passed through a second prism, it does not split further. This proves that the individual colours of the spectrum are pure and cannot be broken down further.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Individual colours of the spectrum are pure colours. When passed through another prism, they bend but do not split further. Only white light (a mixture of all colours) can be dispersed.

questions.question_text: Explain why we can see the reflection of trees in still water but not in flowing (disturbed) water.

options.text: Flowing water absorbs all the light
Still water acts as a smooth reflector (regular reflection), while disturbed water scatters light (irregular reflection)
Trees only reflect in still water due to temperature
Flowing water moves too fast for light to reflect

questions.explanation_correct: Still water has a smooth, flat surface that reflects light in a regular manner (regular reflection), forming a clear image. Disturbed or flowing water has an uneven surface that scatters light in many directions (irregular/diffuse reflection), so no clear image is formed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is about the nature of reflection: smooth surfaces give regular reflection (clear images), rough surfaces give irregular/diffuse reflection (no clear image). Still water is smooth; disturbed water is rough.

questions.question_text: A plane mirror can form a real image under certain conditions.
questions.explanation_correct: A plane mirror always forms virtual images. The reflected rays diverge and only appear to meet behind the mirror. A plane mirror can never form a real image regardless of the position of the object.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. Plane mirrors always form virtual images. There is no condition under which a single plane mirror can form a real image.

questions.question_text: A student observes the image of a distant tree in a concave mirror. The image will be:

options.text: Real, inverted, and very small (near the focus)

questions.explanation_correct: When the object is very far (at infinity), parallel rays converge at the focus of a concave mirror. The image is real, inverted, very small (almost a point), and formed at the focal point.
questions.explanation_incorrect: For a very distant object, a concave mirror forms a real, inverted, and highly diminished image near its focus. Erect and magnified images occur only when the object is very close.

questions.question_text: The scientist who first demonstrated the dispersion of white light using a prism was Isaac ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Sir Isaac Newton performed the famous prism experiment demonstrating that white light is composed of seven colours. He passed sunlight through a glass prism and observed the spectrum.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Newton'. Isaac Newton conducted the pioneering experiment on dispersion of white light using a glass prism.

questions.question_text: A student places a mirror on the floor and stands on it. What will the student see in the mirror?

options.text: Nothing, because the mirror is on the floor

questions.explanation_correct: Looking down at a mirror on the floor, the student would see the soles of their shoes reflected. The mirror reflects light from what is directly above it (the student's feet/shoes) back to the observer's eyes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A mirror reflects light from objects in front of it. Standing on a mirror and looking down, you see the reflection of the bottom of your shoes (the soles), which are closest to the mirror.

questions.question_text: Give two differences between a concave mirror and a convex mirror.

options.text: Concave: converging, can form real images; Convex: diverging, always forms virtual images
Concave: diverging, always virtual images; Convex: converging, always real images
Both are converging and form real images
Both are diverging and form virtual images

questions.explanation_correct: A concave mirror converges light and can form both real and virtual images depending on object position. A convex mirror diverges light and always forms virtual, erect, diminished images.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Concave mirrors converge light and can form real or virtual images. Convex mirrors diverge light and always form virtual images. They have opposite properties.

questions.question_text: A man of height 180 cm wants to see his full image in a plane mirror. What is the minimum height of the mirror required?
questions.explanation_correct: To see a full image in a plane mirror, the mirror needs to be at least half the height of the person. For a 180 cm person, the minimum mirror height is 180/2 = 90 cm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The minimum mirror size to see a complete image is half the height of the object. This is because of the way light reflects: a mirror at eye level needs to extend from mid-forehead to mid-feet level, which is half the total height.

questions.question_text: A student wants to create an artificial rainbow at home. What materials and conditions would be needed?

options.text: A mirror and a dark room
A glass prism or water spray and sunlight
A magnifying glass and a candle
Two plane mirrors placed parallel to each other

questions.explanation_correct: To create an artificial rainbow, you need a source of white light (like sunlight) and something to disperse it (a glass prism, or a fine spray of water). Standing with the sun behind you and spraying water creates tiny droplets that disperse sunlight into rainbow colours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A rainbow needs dispersion of white light. This requires sunlight and something to disperse it: a prism or water droplets. Mirrors alone do not disperse light, and magnifying glasses focus light rather than disperse it.
